Award.AwardTitle: International: Graduate Student Collaboration with ETH Zurich in Polymer Electronics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Doctoral Dissertation Enhancement Project award will provide support for a University of Denver PhD graduate student in computer engineering to spend several months working at ETH in Zurich, Switzerland. While at Denver, the student has developed a novel polymer electronic device. The collaboration with ETH will allow the student to develop novel, low-cost processing techniques for these devices based on micro- and inkjet fabrication methods. This project leverages the research projects currently underway in the NSF supported I/UCRC Safety, Security and Rescue Research Center.

The project has significant broader impacts. The PhD student will have the opportunity to work in a leading European laboratory equipped with state-of-the-art equipment. The collaboration with international scientists and students will expose the student to new ways of conducting science and lead to an international network of future potential collaborators. The project linkage to a I/URCRC will also benefit the members of the center consortium.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT FOR NSF AWARD # 1053249
University of Denver
Project title - International: Graduate Student Collaboration with ETH Zurich in Polymer Electronics

A graduate student, Robert A. Nawrocki, from University of Denver participated in this project and visited and collaborated with Institute of Robotics and Intelligent Systems (IRIS) at Eidgenössische Technische Hochschule Zürich (ETHZ), Zürich, Switzerland. A conference paper, entitled “Wireless Electrical Power to Sub-millimeter Robots,” is submitted to 2011 IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Automation (ICRA 2012) .

The research aimed at finding possible ways of providing electrical power, on sub-millimeter scale, to provide a form of on-board information processing (cognition) to microrobots. A sub-millimeter coil, created using a new, two-photon-absorption, true-three-dimensional-photolithography process, that would generate voltage due to electromagnetic induction was chosen. A two-photon-absorption, true-three-dimensional-photolithography was verified as a possible technique to produce a sub-millimeter coil with the intention of electromagnetic induction was verified. Voltage generation due to electromagnetic induction on sub-millimeter scale was shown as a viable option to power sub-millimeter scale electronics.

INI, or Institute of Neuroinformatics, is a research institute at ETHZ with the goal of “discover[ing] the key principles by which brains work and to implement these in artificial systems that interact intelligently with the real world”. A number of helpful discussions with researchers from the institute were carried out with possible future collaborations. CapoCaccia, a neuromorphic cognition engineering workshop was attended.


Last Modified: 09/28/2011
Modified by: David Wenzhong Gao
